channel.title: Community Involvement – North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies
channel.description: Better nannying for North Carolina starts here!

image.title: Community Involvement – North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies

item.title: National Domestic Workers Alliance Town Hall Call
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: The National Domestic Workers Alliance is concerned about the cost, availability, and pay of childcare in North Carolina. They are hosting a Town Hall call to determine the issues that we face as childcare workers in North Carolina, as well as the childcare needs, so that they can propose political action to help everyone succeed; more care for the children who need it, affordable to the parents, but still a living wage to us.
item.content:encoded:
The National Domestic Workers Alliance is concerned about the cost, availability, and pay of childcare in North Carolina. They are hosting a Town Hall call to determine the issues that we face as childcare workers in North Carolina, as well as the childcare needs, so that they can propose political action to help everyone succeed; more care for the children who need it, affordable to the parents, but still a living wage to us.

If you are willing to offer your time and talent (in other words to attend the call and offer feedback), please sign up. It is free. And it helps all nannies of North Carolina for us to be represented.

The call will take place on Thursday, October 27th 2022 from 6:30 to 8:30 pm. [calendar entry]

And, if nothing else, you can share this post so that it can get attention and we can truly show up as the best state we know we are!

item.title: 2022 Walk-a-thon Fundraiser for the Nanny Relief Fund
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: The Nanny Relief Fund is having a Walk-a-thon Fundraiser and the Nannies of North Carolina are challenging the rest of the world!
item.content:encoded:
The Nanny Relief Fund is having a Walk-a-thon Fundraiser and the Nannies of North Carolina are challenging the rest of the world!

Before you scroll further, if you are a current NC PAN supporting member, log in! There are portions of this post that only you can see!

If you are willing to offer your time and talent aka walk (and since this is virtual you can walk anywhere at any time!), please sign up ($15 fee) to be part of the team of NC nannies — organized by the My Girl Friday nanny agency. Just click the “Join the Team” button on the sign-up page.

SUPPORTING MEMBERS ONLY

If you would like to walk and have your miles counted for the North Carolina nannies team, but do not wish to contribute the $15 to the Nanny Relief Fund, you may join our existing group account and log your miles in aggregate with the rest of us.

The log-in information is as follows:
Username: HarleyPCaley@rhyta.com
Password: Saeph7cie

If you can donate treasure but not time or talent, your North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies have a donation challenge to meet! Donate here https://www.charityfootprints.com/portal/goal_payment/index/58335/onkkqfoz

And, if nothing else, you can share this post so that our state-wide team efforts can get attention and we can truly show up as the best state we know we are!

item.title: Children’s Mental Health Week 2022
item.dc:creator: NC PAN Webmaster
item.description: In the United Kingdom, there is a week in February devoted to the mental health of children. We think this is fabulous! And so, we are doing our part to bring that week here to this side of the Atlantic. This year’s theme is Growing Together. Growing Together is about growing emotionally and finding ways to help […]
item.content:encoded:
In the United Kingdom, there is a week in February devoted to the mental health of children. We think this is fabulous! And so, we are doing our part to bring that week here to this side of the Atlantic.

This year’s theme is Growing Together. Growing Together is about growing emotionally and finding ways to help each other grow. Challenges and setbacks can help us to grow and adapt and trying new things can help us to move beyond our comfort zone into a new realm of possibility and potential. However, emotional growth is often a gradual process that happens over time, and sometimes we might feel a bit ‘stuck’. As caregivers/nannies, we play an important role in our charges’ mental health.

We’re participating!

Our schedule of activities follows. As always, we’d love your photographs of works in progress or works completed. Sharing with other nannies is informal education and perhaps your charge and yourself can be the mentor this time.

  • Monday (7 February): we introduce Watch one growth story and use it to start a conversation with our charge(s) about growth and the different challenges we may face. More information here.
  • Tuesday (8 February): who supports With our charge(s) we will complete this art activity to help them think about who supports them to grow.
  • Wednesday (9 February): the hard thing We will model to our charge(s) how to choose a difficult task. We will choose ours, and they must choose theirs. We then set aside an age/stage appropriate amount of time for us to each independently practice our chosen task. At the conclusion, we debrief about how we felt before, during, and after the task. We then use art materials to remind ourselves not to get distracted by dissuading feelings when we felt so much better after the practice. Resilience researcher Duckworth (2018) explains her rule in this short video.
  • Thursday (10 February): already grown With our charges(s) we will complete this art activity to support our charge(s) to look back at their past growths. Success breeds success.
  • Friday (11 February): work-week close out Watch a second growth story with our charge(s) and use it to start a conversation assessing how the activities this week have emboldened our charges to resiliently face the future. More information here.
  • Saturday (12 February): professional development Learn “How to Manage Your Child’s Emotions (and Your Own)” from the 2021 Happily Family Conference via on demand encore for Supporting Nannies. Supporting Nannies who are logged in to their account will find the link here: [membership level=”1″]https://vimeo.com/670458923[/membership]. This encore is for 24 hours only, so plan ahead and schedule time! For the general public, we offer you this link instead.
  • Sunday (13 February): movie night; 8 pm Join us for an online viewing of “Finding Nemo“, a movie about a fish who is not afraid to face challenges and grow through them and the adult who is making classic caregiver mistakes and has to learn to trust in the young one’s growth as well. Here’s the join link; all are invited.

item.title: Walk-a-thon Fundraiser for the Nanny Relief Fund
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: The Nanny Relief Fund is having a Walk-a-thon Fundraiser and the Nannies of North Carolina are challenging the rest of the world! If you are willing to offer your time and talent aka walk (and since this is virtual you can walk anywhere at any time!), please sign up ($25 fee) to be part of […]
item.content:encoded:
The Nanny Relief Fund is having a Walk-a-thon Fundraiser and the Nannies of North Carolina are challenging the rest of the world!

If you are willing to offer your time and talent aka walk (and since this is virtual you can walk anywhere at any time!), please sign up ($25 fee) to be part of the NC Nannies team. Photos attached to this post tell you how to do that.

If you can donate treasure but not time or talent, your North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies have a donation challenge to meet! Donate here https://runsignup.com/ncpan

And, if nothing else, you can share this post so that our state-wide team efforts can get attention and we can truly show up as the best state we know we are!

item.title: Help Create a Job Description for the word “Nanny”
item.dc:creator: NC PAN Webmaster
item.description: Until now, in the United States, only the IRS bothered to define the job of “nanny” and for legal purposes we have been using that definition ever since. But you notice how that sentence started: until now. What has changed now? Everything! The US Department of Labor through their O*Net (stands for “occupation network”) is […]
item.content:encoded:
Until now, in the United States, only the IRS bothered to define the job of “nanny” and for legal purposes we have been using that definition ever since. But you notice how that sentence started: until now. What has changed now? Everything!

The US Department of Labor through their O*Net (stands for “occupation network”) is looking to create a better definition of the occupation we know as “nanny”. And they want experienced nannies to tell them what it should be and correct their missteps on what it isn’t.

Here is what they’ve got so far.

And here is how you can give your feedback: Send an email to Matt Robinson at RTI International if you are someone who qualifies as an expert. What are the qualifications for expertise? We’ll let Nanny Magazine take if from here:

Compensation might be available if you are selected to be on the panel, and it is enough to subscribe to Nanny Magazine! (there’s our little plug for getting you even more connected to nanny happenings)

item.title: (triangle) Hair Donation Party
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: When: June 22nd @ 12 noon Where: Private Home of Hostess in Durham, NC NC PAN secretary Caroline H and NC PAN Treasurer Jennifer L have been growing their hair out to donate to charity. Come and party with them as they get their locks chopped off for charity, and maybe donate some hair of […]
item.content:encoded:
When: June 22nd @ 12 noon

Where: Private Home of Hostess in Durham, NC

NC PAN secretary Caroline H and NC PAN Treasurer Jennifer L have been growing their hair out to donate to charity. Come and party with them as they get their locks chopped off for charity, and maybe donate some hair of your own, too?!

Bring a snack, snips (hair scissors), or strands!

RSVP on Facebook or by messaging secretary Caroline!

item.title: We Harvested Some Books! 2018
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: On the 25th of August, a modest team of NC PAN nannies showed up at the Book Harvest of Durham to help sort books for children. We had laughs, we had fun, we made our community better, and best of all: we got to keep whatever adult books we wanted! (SO many to choose from!) […]
item.content:encoded:
On the 25th of August, a modest team of NC PAN nannies showed up at the Book Harvest of Durham to help sort books for children.

We had laughs, we had fun, we made our community better, and best of all: we got to keep whatever adult books we wanted! (SO many to choose from!)

If you didn’t make it this time, we’d love to see you the next time we do this event. Don’t miss it! Join the Friends of NC PAN mailing list to find out all that we have planned.

Memories

item.title: (triangle) Harvest Some Books 2018

It’s at 2501 University Drive, Durham, NC 27707 from 9-noon. Contact treasurer@ncpan.org for more details! Open to anyone who wants to help out. Just have them RSVP so that our numbers are accurate! Event Details & […]
item.content:encoded:
Invitation & RSVP: Book Sorting with Book Harvest (Community Involvement)

We have a volunteer outing with Book Harvest to sort books. It’s at 2501 University Drive, Durham, NC 27707 from 9-noon.

Contact treasurer@ncpan.org for more details!

Open to anyone who wants to help out. Just have them RSVP so that our numbers are accurate!

Event Details & RSVP

What: Book Sorting with Book Harvest (Community Involvement)
Who: North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies
When: Sat August 25, 2018, 9 am – noon EST
Where: Book Harvest
2501 University Drive, Durham, NC 27707

RSVP: https://www.facebook.com/events/231795920932066/

item.title: Postcards for National Nanny Recognition Week
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: You know the North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies for our program of sending your employer a really great National Nanny Recognition Week postcard. We love seeing them posted in honored places and love that our member nannies are recognized without having to do the uncomfortable and demanding thing of asking employers to recognize them. […]
item.content:encoded:
You know the North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies for our program of sending your employer a really great National Nanny Recognition Week postcard. We love seeing them posted in honored places and love that our member nannies are recognized without having to do the uncomfortable and demanding thing of asking employers to recognize them. Yuck, so awkward.

One thing we haven’t loved, though, is the breach of trust between a nanny and his/her employer family.

When you ask us to mail your employers a postcard, you must give us private information about your employers and their addresses.

While we always scrupulously honored this private information, using it only to mail out postcards and then annihilating all traces of it from the internet and from our own internal database, it nonetheless had to exist and had to be handed over.

We didn’t love that.

We are nannies, too. We know just how zealously you wish to guard your employers’ information. We do the same.

We’ve solved it!

Rather than providing us with information to mail your employer a postcard, we are providing you with a way to print and fold your own postcards.

They are still professionally designed, still from the North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies, still informative rather than demanding, and still will not make you appear greedy or demanding. But now, you don’t need to tell us who you work for or where they live.

When you “buy” (it is $0, but we don’t know what other word to use) the National Nanny Recognition Week post card from the Equipment Shop, you will be sent a digital file to print, fold, and glue. Then address it and stick a single postcard stamp upon the post card and toss that bad boy in the mail and watch your employer hang the postcard in a place of honor to help them remember to recognize you.

NO

BREACH

OF

INFORMATION

NEEDED!

Just another way the North Carolina Professional Association of Nannies is helping you be the very best nanny you can possibly be!

… that’s nice, but I really liked having NC PAN mail the post card to my employers.

We see you! And we have a solution for you. You can purchase a mailer add-on to your digital post card.

We’ll print it. We’ll address it. And we’ll pop it in the mail for you so that you don’t have to fuss with post card stamps or recognizable handwriting.

We’ll treat your employer’s address with the utmost of our usual data privacy: we scrub it from our minds, computers, and the internet as soon as we’ve addressed the post card for you.

Shop now

item.title: We Harvested Some Books!
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Levenbook
item.description: On the 9th of January, a modest team of NC PAN nannies showed up at the Book Harvest of Durham to help sort books for children. We had laughs, we had fun, we made our community better, and best of all: we got to keep whatever adult books we wanted! (SO many to choose from!) […]
item.content:encoded:
On the 9th of January, a modest team of NC PAN nannies showed up at the Book Harvest of Durham to help sort books for children.

We had laughs, we had fun, we made our community better, and best of all: we got to keep whatever adult books we wanted! (SO many to choose from!)

If you didn’t make it this time, we’d love to see you the next time we do this event. Don’t miss it! Join the Friends of NC PAN mailing list to find out all that we have planned.

Photos

​We would like to invite you to share your photos from the event. Email them to webmaster@ncpan.org.
